Alia's character was living in typical Muslim family that she has limited social attachment where it made her bit of narrow mided and at the same time she was bit of understanding since she was educated. Otherhand, Sky was the opposite character that lives in different country and culture who understands the practicality and social requirements. The film which revolves around story of a GULLY BOY who aspires to become a RAP STAR, which was quite an entry for the BOLLYWOOD into the newest genre of hip-hop hitting the Background Score and the Album Hits. Music has undergone changes from Party Songs, EDM, Remixes and Remakes uptil 2019, but Gully Boy has set up the stage for Music Industry in Bollywood. Director of Photography creates magic with precise arial shots over the Mumbai Slums. A lot of stunts in "Meri Gully Mein", designed by Bosco-Ceaser were marvelous and jaw dropping. Some of them were so fluent didnt seem real, if it wasent then commends the handling by VFX Team. The movie mostly stands out in its dialogues with all the Tapori Dialogues failing to catch sometimes but keeps you entertained throughout. But with dialogues limited, the film was most about expressions by Ranveer and Alia. The stellar performance by award winners of 2018, winning hearts again this year. The support cast by Kalki, Siddhant, Vijay Raaz, Vijay Verma on pars with the lead of the film. The story seems a lot more predictable, plots unneeded, actions unjustified, and 150 mins long movie. The direction of the movie was great as the movie justified Murad's story with other characters in his circle. The story showed the true feminism with Alia Bhatt's continuation of her studies. The story sewed to show how relationship of Murad stands out with all the people in his cirle of friends, mentor, affair, girlfriend, family with abusive father, etc. The cliffhanger by Zoya Akhtar was the best part in the film yet she discloses the suspense very next second.

Gully Boy directed by Zoya Akhter is an upbeat, excellent find of underdog dreams that has amusing optimism, natural entertainment and surprising authenticity. Not only is it the most audaciously explorative Hindi film of the year, it's the most raw, too. 
For a film that frequently comments on the life of poverty and the life of the rich, Gully Boy is an instant crowdpleaser which India sorely needs. Director Zoya Akhter uses even the storytelling as a metaphor, which is... unusual for Hindi cinema.

Being a musical drama, at first I had my skepticism. As many films in the past failed to impress me those who belonged to the same genre. But surprisingly that is not the case with this one. Built and crafted around real life circumstances and everyday struggles ; it perfectly found balance between making a fantasy comes true type of story and a portrayal of a real life rapper. Accompanied with a brilliantly done soundtrack that fits so well with the story, it amazes us in every other aspects well. Outstanding performances from every lead actor, well developed characters, and great cinematography made it great altogether! Though in the first portion of the 2nd half slowed down, it catches the rhythm in the end nonetheless. I have a little complaint about the screen time given to Vijay Raj and Sidhant Chaturvedi's characters ; they deserved much more for their characters in my opinion. The emotional touch could have been better with that. Overall a must watch for those people who loves music, especially Rap/Hip-Hop scene in India. And for those people who have passion about anything, this movie will inspire everyone to make their dream true. Everything is possible if you think so. Believe in yourself that's the true moral comes out of it!

Gullyboy is a masterpiece. It's raw, real, authentic and energetic. It is engaging, intense and soft at the same time. Despite of the fact that the movie is shot in the most poverty stricken area in Mumbai, the backdrops used throughout the movie are a visual treat. The cinematography has played a huge role in how the movie unfolds on the silver screen. The movie is creatively shot from an angle of different characters and the nooks and corners of the slum to give it an authentic feel and make the audience perceive the world from the pov of the movie characters.

It's a musical tale told and directed beautifully with such love and passion for each character. The movie is heartwarming and inspirational.

Ranveer has done it once again. He makes me fall in love with him again and again with his marvelous performances. He kept reminding me of Kabir.. Sensitive and lovable character he played in Zoya Akhtar's last film 'Dil Dhadakane Do'. But his performance in this movie is something else. He has shined in each and every scene as an underdog trying to fight his destiny and in the process discovering the artist within.

The character of Murad is so well written, directed and performed that nowhere in the film he is shown to have an air or swagger about himself or of a hero. He is portrayed to be this frustrated and unsure youth who is going through a phase where he is coming to a realization that he wants to do something else and not be a servant like his father and makes a promise to himself that he will change his reality to match his dreams and that's when he writes the lyrics of ''apana time aayega...' not knowing the rap will actually become a hit and lend him a big break.

Ranveer gave his 200% to perform the role of Murad. He has acted and expressed the feelings of dismay, anger, frustration and love with his eyes, body language and subtle gestures and nuances. He is a gem and I don't think any other actor could have performed this role better than him.

Alia is superb as Safeena. Loved her character and her love for Murad. Their love story is also beautifully told. The very first scene of the two together is so pleasant and refreshing. Audience laughed and applauded whenever Alia shined on the screen with her witty dialogues. The biggest applaud I heard was when she recited the 'liver transplant' lines. Kudos to Alia for looking and speaking like the character with such ease.

The movie also has 4 other powerhouse performances. The characters of MC Sher, Moeen and Murad's parents are all very well written, plotted and performed. Kalki's characterization was OK I think.

The introducing actor Siddhant Chaturvedi who played Murad's guide/mentor/friend gave an impactful performance. He was really good in the raps 'Gully mein' and 'Sher'. Couple of lines he spoke stuck with me. "Apane andar ka lava fatt ke bahar aan de..." and "Tune likha hai to tu suna... Main apane gaane khud likhata hoon". There is so much depth in these lines.

All 18 rap tracks are interwoven in the movie so well. Most of them are played as background scores and help move the storyline forward. But the ones that are actually shot as songs are a treat to the eyes and ears. My favorites are 'Doori' 'Meri Gully Mein' 'Sher aaya Sher' 'Azadi' and of course 'Apana time Aayega'. Just loved the build up of 'Apana time Aayega' and the way it is lined up and staged in the movie. The picturization of this song is amazing as we all know but seeing it on the big screen in the context of the story line is just another experience altogether. Ranveer is electrifying in this very happening and moving rap 'Apana time Aayega'.

My favorite lines from the movie- "koi dusara mereko batayega main kaun hai..." and "main apani reality change karoonga apane sapano se mel khane ke liye.."

The movie is loosely based on the life of Mumbai rappers 'Divine' and 'Naezy' and beautifully put together and expressed by the brilliant film director Zoya Akhtar. Loved every bit of it ï¿ 1/2 1/2'-

Zoya Akhtar is known for making "rich people" films. She shows lives most people may aspire to but may never actually live. With Gully Boy, she makes an attempt to earn some "street cred" and takes us to the streets of Bombay, which of course means, Dharavi. What follows is what you would expect from a film about a struggling artist from such a place - shots of the slums and "gullys", small homes, people struggling for basic needs, and so on.

It is not that it is not done well, but it's just that these montages have become so common, one is almost immune to feeling any sort of emotion when one sees them. Still, Zoya really tries to show the contrast between the two Mumbai's from the eyes of Muraad, the soon-to-be Gully Boy and for the most part, succeeds.

MC Sher, Muraad's eventual mentor, roars onto the screen and stays with you after the movie. His screen presence is beyond what you would expect from a newcomer. But Siddhant, the actor playing the part, stands on his own in front of Ranveer's Muraad. Given their age difference (Siddhant is 25 and Ranveer is 33), it was a clever move to have him put on weight while Ranveer lost quite a few pounds.

Some parts of the movie are laugh out loud funny. A witty dialogue (or rap) here, a bottle being broken on someone's head there. Overall, the movie keeps its serious tone without going full dramatic on you.

The first half drags though and barely has much to write about. The struggles of the family that barely gets by are so overdone that even though they are necessary in a film like this, you don't want to sit through all of it. The good bits are when there is music and rapping going on screen (or in the background).

Alia plays the female lead and provides some more comic relief from time to time. Her equation with Ranveer is delicately handled. The kissing scenes may make parents uncomfortable (if you make the mistake of watching with them) but they don't take away from the story and actually help show how far back their relationship goes in a subtle way. I kept wishing someone else had played the role instead of Alia though.

The second half is where the real "hiphop" begins, with Ranveer finding his voice and footing as a rapper and standing on MC Sher's shoulders to reach higher. It was a good decision having Ranveer voice all the songs he had to perform throughout the movie. However, for normal dialogues, you never quite lose the feeling that it's Ranveer doing an accent.

The "Apna Time Aayega" song gives you goosebumps because by then, you are invested in Muraad's story, even if you are still distant. Him getting to open for a big name artist, standing on a grand stage is a fitting ending too.

Unlike Zoya's other films, Gully Boy is unlikely to be something you watch again and again. Hopefully, the soundtrack will help keep the movie alive in your mind for a bit longer but as time goes by and you lose context, those tracks are going to be deleted from your phone.

The only downside of the film is the length and it is 30 mins too long.

Gully Boy Movie Review: Apna Time Aayega!

When you leave the movie theater after watching Gully Boy, all that goes through your mind is APNA TIME AAYGA! and rightfully so! The song is very cleverly written and highly addicting. 

Review: [Weï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)ll keep it as spoiler free as possible]

The Story

Gully Boy is a story about a boy called Murad (played brilliantly by Ranveer Singh) in his 20s who while trying to find his identity has to cope with the harsh reality of life around him.  He finds his outlet by expressing himself through writing rhymes and raps in his little notepad. He lives through emotional pain and poverty and once he finds his passion for rap, he decides to make rap his way out of the slums and make a name for himself. 

The story of Gully Boy is loosely inspired by many rappers from the Indian rap scene but mainly DIVINE and NEASY. The story is not a biopic and even though the character in Gully Boy are all fictional, they feel very real and for that all the credits go to the director and the actors. Gully Boy at no time feels like a movie. When watching, you feel for the characters (each one of them). 

The Actors

Letï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s start with Ranveer Singh: Weï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)ve often described Ranveer Singh as an actor of great potential but with tendencies of overacting quite a bit. This is totally not the case in Gully Boy. Ranveer Singh is in his element here. So much so that you totally buy him in his Murad character and donï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t see him as Ranveer Singh and for that, our hats off to the star. He has improved himself so much and is truly ruling over Bollywood right now. Another point that needs to be highlighted is the female lead and characters. Alia Bhatt shines in her role as Safeena and is given a full story arc and proper character development. Actually, speaking of character development, each actor and character have been giving the proper story arch and development that one can make a movie on each character and it would work. MC Sher (played by Siddant Chaturvedi) is brilliant and we would not mind if he would get a spin-off movie on his own. 

The Songs

OMG! Again, the songs are amazing. Each song not only comes at the right time but has a strong emotion connection and carries the movie forward. That said, the best song of the movie has to be Apna Time Aayega. By the time it comes on, the song feels earned that it sends a shivering down your spine. Its emotional and it gives a sense of achievement. Youï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)ve been on a journey with Murad and youï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)ve witnessed this song being made during the whole movie. 

The Good

Every single aspect of the movie is good, there are no bad parts of the movie. Even though the movie is 2.5 hours long, it feels like itï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)s too short. By the end of it, you feel like begging the director to show a little bit more, to let you spend just a few more minutes with Muradï¿ 1/2 1/2 We really hope that Gully Boy gets a sequel and that Zoya Akhtar comes back for it. She really delivers on the directors end and so do the actors on their end. 

Should I watch it?

8 Mile in Mumbai. Executive producer rapper NAS supported Bollywood director Zoya Akhtar bringing her vision of a slum kid rising through rap battle ranks to find his voice in Gully Boy. This is one of the best films of any kind that I have seen in a while. Lead male, Ranveer Singhâ(TM)s  titular Gully  Boy, Murad, draws us in with his introversion. Lead female, Alia Bhattâ(TM)s Safeena is banging on the walls of Muslim tradition, in a story that Americans do not see every day, but we all know. Safeena sneeks around and hides her affection for Murad from her traditional parents. There are a raft of great supporting performances, none more so that Muradâ(TM)s street associate Moeen played by Vijay Varma. A rap film has to have that buddy / dealer / hustler who will ends up on the wrong side of bars or the ground, yet who at some critical moment will bring a light of wisdom to goings on.
 
The arc of the story has no surprises, but the magic lies in the telling of the story. Akhtar introduces us to Murad and Safeena on a city bus in a visually comfortable dance with no words. I have seen a lot of slick Bollywood productions, and this is somehow better. The claustrophobia and well-worn grime of the Mumbai slums is a vital character here. The camera glides and circles the characters, catching every important nuance so perfectly there are nearly no flaws to find. At one point some westerners on tour of slums, pay to peek in real peopleâ(TM)s homes, gawking at how tiny shacks and shanties can accommodate so many people, out loud, with the residents right there! While I have always found the Bollywood insistence of musical dance numbers a bit awkward, Gully Boyâ(TM)s inserts of them in the context of rap videos seems the most natural I have ever seen. It almost caught me by surprise to realize; oh this is the obligatory dance number. If I have a knit to pick, Singh at 32 is a bit old to be playing the 21 year old of the story. But if the character were older, I would call this casting flawless. The post intermission film is also a little short of the magic of the incredibly amazing 1st half. If Indian tradition permitted, a shorter more edited story would have been even better. 

What can I say, Story: good, Acting: great, Cinematography: great, Music: great, Directing: Freaking Great!

"Gully Boy" is a fully fresh and modern story that Bollywood should be proud to claim. This movie was consistently entertaining and a captivating character piece that is also very entertaining. The movie covers a lot of ground when it comes to social issues, and it feels like it covers just a bit too much. If it focused up a bit more on its central theme and was a tad bit shorter, it could have been a nearly flawless movie. Nonetheless, I appreciated all of the bold statements the movie presented. The lead performance from Ranveer Singh is outstanding and his flawed yet likable character is one I was able to root for from the getgo. Bollywood movies frequently include memorable soundtracks but in this movie, the music really stands out. The lyrics go well with the movie's storyline and every rap sequence was like a shot of adrenaline. I thought it was fascinating to see what the hip-hop scene in India is like and the soundtrack is clearly well thought out. This movie carries lots of emotional weight, showcases strong characters, and is entertaining pretty much all the way through. It has set the bar high for Bollywood in 2019.
